docs.lead_paragraph: CLEAR SPRINGS A Memoir By Bobbie Ann Mason 298 pages. Random House. $25. In her novels and short stories, Bobbie Ann Mason limned a New South reeling from the dislocations of modern life, a place where the old certainties of family and religion are slipping away and small towns and family farms have been replaced by malls and subdivisions and fast-food joints. In her new memoir, ''Clear Springs,'' she returns to the region of western Kentucky she has depicted so many times before, but she gives us her own memories of the area, before it was flung so precipitously into the 20th century by World War II and the incursion of radio and television and film.

headline.main: Memories of Her Old Kentucky Home Trace the Roots of an Author's Fiction

docs.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has decided not to sell an emergency contraceptive approved last year for sale in the United States and widely available in drugstores nationwide. The company stated in a letter to Planned Parenthood that it had made a ''business decision'' not to fill prescriptions for Preven, which stops ovulation and may prevent fertilized eggs from becoming implanted in the uterus. The drug, manufactured by Gynetics Inc. of Somerville, N.J., is recommended for use up to 72 hours after unprotected sex and is sometimes called a ''morning after'' pill.

headline.main: Wal-Mart Decides Against Selling a Contraceptive

docs.abstract: Walt-Mart Stores Inc has decided not to sell Gynetics Inc's drug Preven, emergency contraceptive approved last year for sale in US and widely available in drugstores nationwide; Wal-Mart, in letter to Planned Parenthood, says it has made 'business decision' not to fill prescriptions for Preven, which is recommended for use up to 72 hours after unprotected sex and is sometimes called 'morning after' pill; Planned Parenthood, critical of Wal-Mart's decision, says it suspects store's policy might stem from pressure from people who say life beings moment egg is fertilized (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Heinz Werner Berendes, a pediatrician and medical epidemiologist for the National Institutes of Health who pioneered studies of birth-control safety and the care of newborns, died on May 6 at the N. I. H. Clinical Center in suburban Maryland. He was 74 and lived in Bethesda, Md. The cause was prostate cancer, said the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, where he was a senior investigator. Mr. Berendes directed the perinatal research branch and the groundbreaking Collaborative Perinatal Project, the largest such effort this country.

headline.main: Heinz Werner Berendes, 74, Pioneer in the Care of Newborns

docs.lead_paragraph: The Big Flap To become airborne, a plane must reach a critical speed as it rolls down the runway. Below this limit -- 150 miles an hour, say, for a jet under certain conditions -- the plane stays on the tarmac.
docs.abstract: Researchers at San Diego and Los Angeles County natural history museums suggest that flapping wings of archaeopteryx, earliest known bird, could generate both thrust and lift, enabling it to fly; reseachers find evidence that African elephant had a marine past; German scientists discover that flowers of a tropical vine have acoustical property that enables bats to find and pollinate them (M)

A1 Chinese officials choreographed relentless protests directed against the American Embassy in Beijing yesterday, but this morning there were only a few scattered protests outside the compund. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: The ability to do mathematics -- everything from simple arithmetic to thinking up equations that explain an expanding universe -- may stem from the interaction of two brain circuits that handle numbers differently, two scientists have found. In a series of experiments involving bilingual college students, the researchers discovered that one circuit gives names to numbers and carries out exact calculations. A second circuit operates intuitively and is used for estimating quantities and other numerical relationships. During human evolution, they suggest, these two brain areas combined forces and gave rise to the remarkable human capacity for manipulating numbers arithmetically. Their interaction may also underlie many kinds of advanced mathematics.

headline.main: Brain's Math Machine Traced to 2 Circuits

docs.lead_paragraph: Sarah Brady, a crusader for gun control, found common ground with Robert A. Ricker, a lobbyist for gun makers. Steve Case, chairman of America Online, and Doug Lowenstein, a lobbyist for video-game makers, agreed to try to prevent children from buying some games on the Internet. And Eric Heydenberk, 12, of Quakertown, Pa., said he was creating a Web page to tell other kids how to handle being bullied. Lots of small moments emerged today from President Clinton's three-hour ''summit'' meeting on youths and violence, as did a pledge by the Administration to campaign against violence. But one immediate result of the White House talkathon, at which 50 people spoke and which reporters were barred from viewing, was to diffuse blame for the school shooting in Littleton, Colo., in April.
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton holds summit on youths and violence in Washington involving prominent lawmakers, firearms lobbyists, industry leaders and 12-year-old youth; many factors responsible for problem are examined, shifting focus away from guns; immediate result is diffusing of blame for school shootings in Littleton, Colo; Robert A Ricker, lobbyist for gun industry, says atmosphere was constructive and that all agreed that youth violence was vastly complex societal problem; comments by other prominent participants, including Sarah Brady and First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton, noted; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Education Trust's report that low-income students are benefiting from ''higher standards and more personal instruction, parent involvement and teacher accountability'' is encouraging (news article, May 9). But it is time to recognize that the great untapped power in schools is the students themselves.

headline.main: Vouchers Help Those Most in Need

docs.abstract: Frank Riessman letter contends it is time to recognize that great untapped power in schools is students themselves (May 9 article); contends peer programs that give students opportunity to teach and help each other can change turned-off students into engaged members of school community

docs.lead_paragraph: William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, has given $50 million to Columbia University's Joseph L. Mailman School of Public Health for a program to prevent mothers in developing nations from dying during childbirth. The gift is the largest foundation grant for a single program in Columbia's history, said Dr. Allan Rosenfield, the dean of the School of Public Health.

headline.main: Gates Gives $50 Million to Columbia School of Public Health

docs.lead_paragraph: TWINS, these days, seem to be everywhere. Although septuplets and octuplets have attracted national attention lately, statistics show that twin births are up 47 percent nationwide from 1980 to 1996. High-order multiples (triplets or more) are extremely rare. In most multiple births, the babies come in twos, but, even then, carrying them to term isn't always easy.

headline.main: Hands, and Hearts, Filled With Twins
